Only one process in critical section at a time
questions.explanation: Mutual exclusion ensures only one process can execute in its critical section at any time.

questions.prompt: What is the progress requirement for critical section?
questions.explanation: Progress requires that if no process is in CS, selection of next process cannot be delayed indefinitely.

options: Limit on times a process can be bypassed
questions.explanation: Bounded waiting ensures no process waits forever; there's a limit on how often others can enter first.

questions.prompt: Disabling interrupts is a good solution for multiprocessor critical sections.
questions.explanation: Disabling interrupts only works on uniprocessors; other CPUs can still access shared data.
A mutex is a synchronization primitive that provides mutual exclusion through lock/unlock.
A counting semaphore can have any non-negative integer value, controlling access to multiple resources.

questions.prompt: What does wait() (P operation) do to a semaphore?
questions.explanation: Wait decrements the semaphore; if it would become negative, the process blocks.

questions.prompt: What does signal() (V operation) do to a semaphore?
questions.explanation: Signal increments the semaphore value and may wake a blocked process.

questions.prompt: A binary semaphore is equivalent to a mutex in functionality.
questions.explanation: A binary semaphore restricted to 0 and 1 provides the same mutual exclusion as a mutex.

questions.prompt: In producer-consumer, what semaphore tracks empty buffer slots?
questions.explanation: The empty semaphore counts available empty slots for the producer to use.

questions.prompt: In readers-writers, when can a writer write?
options: When no readers or writers are active
When at least one reader is active
questions.explanation: A writer needs exclusive access: no other readers or writers can be in the critical section.

questions.prompt: What causes deadlock in naive dining philosophers?
options: All pick up left fork simultaneously
questions.explanation: If all philosophers pick up their left fork, no one can get their right fork, causing circular wait.
A monitor is a high-level construct that encapsulates shared data with synchronized access methods.

questions.prompt: What do condition variables provide in monitors?
questions.explanation: Condition variables let threads wait for specific conditions and be signaled when conditions change.
